text.p: Following are some of the leading stories in Norwegian papers this morning:
- The Statistics Office has revised upwards forecasts for 1997 Gross Domestic Product (GDP) to 4.8 percent from 4.3 percent and the forecast for the inflation to 2.3 percent from 2.2 percent.

- Telecom Telenor has spent five million crowns in 1996 on making people switch off their mobile phones when going to the theatre, to restaurants and to the cinema. Per Eng Halvorsen, head of information in Telenor, says the company has to fight noise pollution in order not to ruin the market. This week many actors and musicians complained in newspapers about people in the audience receiving calls during performances.

- Thorvald Stoltenberg, former U.N. mediator in the former Yugoslavia, criticizes the United States in a new book. Stoltenberg says the United States did not offer enough support during mediation to end the war in the former Yugoslavia.

- Analyst Tim Whittaker at the Union Bank of Switzerland, Saga Petroleum's financial advisor, says Saga's takeover of Santa Fe Exploration marks a new trend. Good profits in the business and new technology will increase the price of takeovers and mergers, he says.

- Several analysts say the share price of pharmaceutical group Nycomed ASA should be higher than the current level. They say Nycomed is expected to go through a period of growth again in a couple of years.
